Why are we looking for a valid fabric adapter path first? Generally we would want to look for a port with a matching name, then verify that it has a system association.

Doing it the way it's done here results in significantly more dbus calls.

This is for `/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/FabricAdapters/<str>/Ports/<str>/` among many other types of Ports.

Fabric adapter ports are specific to each fabric adapter, and the association is also related to each fabric adapter.
So, to get the port, the fabric adapter path name needs to be obtained.

This commit is doing the followings to find the associated port and it would do 2 dbus calls.

 - GetSubTree() get/validate the fabric adapter path
 - GetAssociatedTreePaths() to get ports using the found fabricAdapterPath.
 
However, if we change to too for ports first, it may end up causing more d-bus calls.

For example, assuming ports exist for other entities, GetSubTree() for a port (e.g. port1) may find this first
- .../network1/port1
- .../storge1/port1
- .../fabric1/port1
- etc

Then, to choose/select the fabric adapter (e.g. fabric1), we may need to call the assoication d-bus calls for each port (as the port-list may be associated with the different types).  
As the result, the total number of dbus could become larger than finding the fabric adapter first.

In addition, for better clarity, I've renamed `port.hpp` to `fabric_ports.hpp`, and rename function names to include `Fabric` e.g. `getValidFabricPortPath()`

We still have multiple dbus calls though?

Here, the query is to get ports of the given/specific adapter (e.g. `disk_backplane0`), not all ports in the system.

```
curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}:18080/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/disk_backplane0/Ports
```


Approach A)

So, the logic flow (by `getValidFabricPortSubTree()`) here is
1) validate the give adapter (`disk_backplane0`) where is it a valid fabric adapter using `getValidFabricAdapterPath()`.  

2) With the validate fabric adapter, the find ports (with the type of `Connector.Port`) that are associated by 'connecting' with the fabric adapter (`disk_backplane0`) in `getFabricAssociatedPortSubTree()`

```
getFabricAssociatedPortSubTree()
{

    dbus::utility::getAssociatedSubTree(
        fabricAdapterPath + "/connecting", 
        ...
}
```
This will return all valid ports of type `Connector.Port` that are associated by `connecting` for the given fabric adapter.  We don't need to validate each port's type again as they are already valid.

---

Approach B)

However, if we do the other way arounds like
1) find all ports with the types of 'Connector.Port'.  This may return the the mix of the ports that may be associated with the other types (e.g. Network).

2) Then, for each port, we need to call 'getAssociatedSubTreePaths()` using `connected_to` for FabricAdapter.

- For example, if (1) returns N items, the step (2) will invoke `getAssociatedSubTreePaths()'  N times.

```
     for(port : subtreepaths)
     {
         getAssociatedSubTreePaths( .. port + "/connected_to", )
     }
```

---

I think Approach (A) is correct and more efficient than (B).
It is because the query is for the already-scoped input (e.g. given adapter).

in nowhere above are you verifying that an item is item.FabricAdapter

the reality here is that this is all business logic that needs to go in the mapper.  we shouldn’t be chaining together multiple calls to dump all ports and all fabric adapters just to get a single port.

because this is the first use of a 2 tiered association (fabric adapter -> association -> port) where we don’t know the type on the other side, it’s not surprising the mapper doesn’t have a method that does what we need here.  making complex code like this in bmcweb is not the answer.  let’s get the mapper updated with a call that does what we need, and returns a single value. Why do we do a full subtree command and then ignore the result?

The function `getValidFabricPortSubTree()` is also used by the other places which use `portSubTree`.

and this is why the callback pattern I described earlier is important.

I would agree to return the error to the caller, if `getValidFabricPortSubTree()` is a generalized wrapper like `getAssociationEndPoints()` etc to make the logic clearer.

However, like this case, `getValidFabricPortSubTree()` is designed to check/handle the error and return the subtree only if it is valid. It is also called by a few places. If so, wouldn't it appropriate to filter out errors to callers?

If not but passing the errors to the callers, would all callers need to handle the same errors and need the similar aux functions - `afterXXX()` again.

> I would agree to return the error to the caller, if `getValidFabricPortSubTree()` is a generalized wrapper like `getAssociationEndPoints()` etc to make the logic clearer.
> 
> However, like this case, `getValidFabricPortSubTree()` is designed to check/handle the error and return the subtree only if it is valid.

Right, and we generally do that by returning an error.  A "handle all possible errors for all possible callers" routine is generally not a pattern that has been found to work.  If it does, having one branch and a method to handle that error in the callback is trivial.

> It is also called by a few places. If so, wouldn't it appropriate to filter out errors to callers?

Generally not, because it:
A. breaks the mental model of async operations.  I will note that the couple of places we break this already have caused a lot of problems in bugs.
B. Doesn't give the caller a chance to customize their error.  Pretty rarely is the error handling identical between two different callers.  The fact that it is in this case stems from the fact that we're doing multiple chained mapper calls, which is not only complex, but shows this issue.

Once we have this down to one mapper call, I'd be really surprised if the error handling had anything common.

> 
> If not but passing the errors to the callers, would all callers need to handle the same errors and need the similar aux functions - `afterXXX()` again.

if (ec){
    handleError();
    return;
}

is a trivial amount of code to write.  Keep in mind that the error for POST is different than the error for GET, is different than the error for an Action, so pretty much all the code will need a customized (to some degree) error handler anyway.
